Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean is married with two children. She is twenty-five years old and resides at Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. Mary Jean operates a food vending business in their barangay (village) to make a living, and she has been operating this business for more than ten years. Each month, she earns about Php 10,000 doing this type of work. 

She has requested a loan in the amount of Php 4,000 to purchase more food to sell. Mary Jean has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, her profits will be used for the educational plan of her two kids, and she is hoping that her small business will grow.

loans.use: to purchase more food to sell.

loans.name: Sozui's Group

texts.en:
Sozui is the leader of this group. She is 55 and unfortunately she is a widow. She has raised three sons and a daughter. Two older sons are married and live separately with their families. The daughter works in a sewing workshop in Bishkek, and the youngest son lives with Sozui. He helps her with livestock breeding. Reselling livestock after fattening, the family earns about 2,000 soms per month. Sozui wants to increase the number of livestock. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase four farm animals for breeding. In the future she wishes to see her youngest son get wed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase farm animals.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a 30-year-old married woman with 2 children who are enrolled in school. Her husband Thomas, who is employed, also contributes to providing for the family's basic needs. Florence owns a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for her children.

Florence has operated a grocery for the past two years; she operates her business from the market. Her potential clients are the people who come to the marketplace to shop, and her major challenge is transportation. She dreams of expanding her business.

She plans to use the loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to purchase more vegetables and foodstuffs for her grocery. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance to access capital to help her expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables and foodstuffs for her grocery.

loans.name: Nassir

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 29 years old, married and a father to one child. 

Nassir has been a shop-owner since 2010, selling household items. He has sufficient experience in this field and a deep understanding of local consumer needs. His shop is situated in a crowded area so there are a good number of customers passing by.

He is requesting a $2400 loan in order to renovate his shop’s walls and floors, to make shelves and to add more inventories. He is aiming to gain more profits to offer him the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: in order to renovate his shop’s walls and floors, to make shelves and to add more inventories.

loans.name: Norway Group

texts.en:
Dastan, who is in his early 30s, is married with triplets who are still young. He has been selling chips and chicken, chips and eggs, and chips and mishikaki for one year now. He works from 8 a.m to 11 p.m. daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be his third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to buy Irish potatoes, pay rent, and take care of his triplets. He has paid back his loans successfully. Dastan wants a loan to buy more sacks of Irish potatoes, chicken, and eggs. His dream is to one day be able to buy a plot of land.

He will share this loan with his loan group, "Norway", which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accoutable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of Irish potatoes, chicken, and eggs.

loans.name: Oganes

texts.en:
Oganes is a young farmer from the village of Atskuri, South Georgia. He is 22 years old and lives with his family: a 20-year-old sister (a student), his parents, an uncle, and his 72-year-old grandmother. 

Family members earn a living through agricultural activities. They have a plot of land where maize and potatoes are grown. Harvested vegetables are sold in nearby villages and towns. The total average monthly income of the family is 550 Laris (approximately $330 USD). 

Oganes requested credit to purchase a horse. He will use it for transportation of harvested products to nearby villages. The family has good conditions for keeping the domestic animal, including a building, which will be used as a stable. The horse will also help Oganes in tilling family-owned lands, where maize will be sown. 

In the future, the family will cultivate more land and sow more corn. Accordingly, their income from corn sales will increase and the family will be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a horse

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen is a widow and mother of two sons. Her husband's death was a very difficult time for her, but she never gave up and started her grocery business at home to raise her children. Now her sons are young and do work. They are involved in an embroidery and sewing business. 

Yasmeen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her eldest son, who wants to buy another sewing machine and clothes for the further expansion of his business. He will also hire a worker, which will allow him to finish the orders on time and increase his sales and profits. He has vast experience in his business and Yasmeen is very confident that an investment will be a productive one for him. She wants him to marry soon and is hopeful that an improved business condition will help her make savings for that purpose.

Note: "In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Yasmeen".

loans.use: to buy another sewing machine and clothes for an embroidery and sewing business

loans.name: Sergio

texts.en:
Sergio is a fisherman from Talibon, Bohol. He is married and has 3 children. Sergio owns a fishing boat that he uses to go fishing. He is able to provide for his family's basic needs through his income. He works hard to improve his business so that he can sustain his children's education.

Sergio has requested a loan to purchase fish nets and other materials. He hopes to earn more so he can pay his children's school fees and make improvements to the family's house.

loans.use: to purchase fish nets and other materials

loans.name: Livingstone

texts.en:
Livingstone is a 39-year-old married man with three children who are enrolled in school. His wife is a businesswoman who contributes to providing for the family's basic needs. Livingstone owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food for his family and school fees for his children.

Livingstone has been working as a photographer for the past 11 years. His potential clients are his neighbors, friends, and relatives. Theft is a major challenge for him. He dreams of owning a photo shop since he currently operates door-to-door.

He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to purchase more cameras and film for his business. He decided to join Yehu Microfinance because it gives loans to low-income earners.

loans.use: To purchase more cameras and film for his business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 48 years old and married. She has seven children aged 28, 25, 23, 20,18,16 and 12 years. She is a farmer and has been in the business for the past 10 years. She gets a monthly income of KES 20,000 from the business.

This is her third loan with KADET LTD. She repaid her previous loans successfully. She will use the loan amount to plant more cabbages on her farm.

She will use the anticipated profit to purchase a piece of land for her farming. Her dream is to increase her income and raise her family in a comfortable lifestyle.

loans.use: to plant more cabbages

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 37 years old and married to Winnie. Together they have two children aged five and two years. He is a farmer and has been in the business for the past six years. He gets a monthly income of KES 30,000 from his business.

This is his third loan term with KADET LTD. He repaid his previous loans successfully. He will use the loan amount to purchase a dairy cow to support his farming business.

He will buy moire dairy cows with the anticipate profit. His dream is to own a dairy farm and have a stable income to educate his children.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella, a 30-year-old married mother of two children, both of whom are in school, has a business selling clothes in Kator, South Sudan. She is married to a businessman. Stella has requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase more clothing to sell, and  will use her extra income to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Jacton

texts.en:
Jacton, a 45-year-old married man who runs a retail shop in Kisimani, Mombasa, was recently introduced to KADET LTD. In business for the last two years, this will mark Jacton’s first loan from KADET LTD which he will use to purchase more stocks of sugar, a variety of cereals, rice and cooking oil for his shop.

Jacton will use the anticipated new profits to repay the loan and gradually expand his business. In future he would like to become a wholesaler.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of sugar, a variety of cereals, rice and cooking oil.

loans.name: Phượng

texts.en:
Phượng is a 43-year-old woman living in the town of Yen Phong distict - Bac Ninh province. She is engaged and has 2 adult-aged children. To making a living, Phượng owns and operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector, operating a furniture-making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling bedroom furniture to local businesses and community members. Phượng has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007, Phượng joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Phượng is now requesting a loan of 8,288,000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings. The loan will be the 6th loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA.  Phượng plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Phượng là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yen Phong distict - Bac Ninh province .  Cô ấy đã đính hôn và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi trưởng thành.  Để kiếm sống, Phượng Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ sản xuất & bán trang thiết bị trong phòng ngủ cho các doanh nghiệp và người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Phượng thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Phượng kiếm được khoảng 5.000.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2007, Phượng đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Phượng đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua nguyên liệu thô bổ sung để mở rộng việc giới thiệu sản phẩm.  Khoản vay sẽ là 6th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  Phượng dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings

loans.name: Truphosa

texts.en: Truphosa, who is 33 years old, married to Patrick, and the mother of two children, has been selling second-hand clothes for the past year, earning a monthly income of KES 2,200. This is her first loan from  KADET LTD, which she will use to buy more second-hand clothes to resell. The anticipated profit will be used to diversify into dairy farming. Her dream is to have a stable dairy farming business.

loans.use: to buy more second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Mart

texts.en:
Mart, an unmarried 24-year-old who lives with her brother in the slum district of Kherlen, is a taxi driver around the Kherlen area. She started her business in 2009 and already has many permanent customers. She recently purchased a newer car, but unfortunately it broke down a month ago and her business is now stopped.

Because of the urgent need to earn a living and save money so that she can enter college and develop a career, she needs this loan to repair her taxi for renewed operation.

loans.use: to repair her taxi.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is 40 years old, a married woman with two children.  Both her children are in school.  For five years, she has been running a business of selling maize grain and beans in Kator, South Sudan.
Victoria requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase beans for sale.  She will use the extra income from this loan to build a house in future.

loans.use: to purchase maize grain and beans for sale.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita is from the village of Cabungaan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental.  She is 77 years old, and is married.  To make a living, Carmelita owns & operates a coconut production business.  Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.  Carmelita is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to pay for coconut harvesting. This will be Carmelita's tenth loan from GDMPC.

In 2007, Carmelita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: to pay for coconut harvesting

loans.name: Miyasuren

texts.en:
Mrs. Miyasuren, 30, is a taxi driver around Kherlen, a border town.  She lives with her son and husband in a old house which is located in the slum district. Just a year ago, she started her taxi business and already has a lot of permanent customers. 
For the past several years, her house has been damaged and requires maintenance and upkeep.  It has a damaged roof, no insulation on the walls, broken windows etc.  Therefore she is taking a loan to purchase the building materials to fix and maintain her old house, before the arrival of the cold winter months.

loans.use: To fix and maintain her old house before this cold winter.

loans.name: Misaidi

texts.en:
Misaidi is a divorced woman with for children who are all enrolled in school. She owns a house with neither electricity nor water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for children.

Misaidi has operated as a food vendor for the past four years; her potential clients are her relatives and friends. She faces a major challenge of seasonality where there is low demand during the rainy season. She aspires to own a hotel in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase beans, wheat flour, cooking oil and set up a place to sell her products. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance to get working capital for her business.

loans.use: To purchase beans, wheat flour, cooking oil and set up a place to sell her products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bags, sandals and shoes

loans.name: Basemera

texts.en:
Basemera is 46 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has four children who are all currently in school. For the past seven years, Basemera has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells food and various household supplies. 

To help expand his business, Basemera has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food products like sugar and flour, and will help Basemera to generate greater profits and improve the quality of life for his family. Basemera hopes that in the future he will be able to turn his shop into a full grocery store. 

Basemera is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Basemera who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more food products like sugar and flour

loans.name: Noel

texts.en: Noel is 26 years old and is a married man with two children aged four and one.  Noel has been a fisherman for five years.  He earns about 10000 PHP through his business.  Noel plans to use his loan to purchase gasoine, plywood, paint, and other materials to renovate his fishing boat.  This will help him to continue earning a living from fishing.  Noel plans to save money for his children's education.

loans.use: to purchase gasoine, plywood, paint, and other materials to renovate his fishing boat.

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en: Narantuya is 40 years old and rents a stall where she sells food commodities in a market called Fresh.  She lives with her two daughters and husband in the boundary district of Ulaanbaatar, in the capital city of Mongolia.  She has been running her business for a year and half.  Mainly she sells fruits from Russia as it is the most popular products of her stall.  Currently she has a plan to increase the working capital for expanding her business.  She will buy bulk amounts of fruits from Russian suppliers.  Therefore she needs two more refrigerators to keep her fruits healthy.  The loan Narantuya is taking will be dedicated to cover the payment of new refrigerators that will keep her fruit fresh.

loans.use: To cover the payment of new refrigerators for her business.

loans.name: Akhmed

texts.en:
Akhmed lives in the village Algeti, Kartli Region. He is 59 years old and lives with his 31 year-old son and 26 year-old daughter-in-law. Akhmed is leading the agricultural business of the family. His son is a worker in the village and daughter-in-law works as a teacher. 

The family owns 0.20 hectare of land, where potatoes are grown.  Also, they have a greenhouse of 500 sq. meters and grow tomatoes there. Akhmed sells harvested vegetables locally to the greengrocery retailers. Total average monthly income of the family is 900 Laris (542 USD). 

Akhmed requested credit to purchase a milk cow. He will sell milk locally and increase the income of the family. The family will use increased income for purchasing additional household goods, to improve family living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school.  Her husband is a businessman who contributes to the provisions of the families basic needs.  She owns a house with electricity and piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

Riziki has operated a lesos selling business for the past three years.  (Lesos are also called kanga. They are the most prominent article of clothing for East African women.)  In addition she also runs a coconut and juice selling business.  Her potential clients are her neighbors and the local area residents.  She faces a major challenge of seasonality as she sells more lesos during the festive seasons.  She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop of selling lesos. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase more stocks of lesos and coconuts for resale.  She decided to join Yehu Microfinance because it has fair legal requirements.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of lesos (kanga) and coconuts for resale.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 34 years old and has four children all of which are in school.  She has had a business as a hotel server in Kator, South Sudan for the past six years. She is married to a business man.

Susan requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase rice and beans for her business.  She will use her profits from this loan to build a concrete house in order to extend the hotel in the future.

loans.use: to purchase rice and beans for her business.

loans.name: Florefes

texts.en: Florefes is a married woman with two children.  She is 52 years old, and resides in Tinacla-an, Clarin Misamis Occidental in the Philippines.  For the past four years, Florefes has owned and operated a general store, selling a variety of different products to earn a living.  Each month, she earns 10,000.00 doing this type of business.  She requested a loan of 10,000.00 to purchase products to resell.  Florefes has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year.  In the future, Florefes wants to build a house and to help her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase products to resell.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam is 38 years old and lives in the town of Nakifuma in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past five years, Miriam has been working hard to manage her boutique, which sells children's clothes. 

To help expand her business, Miriam has requested a loan of 2,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for resale, and will help Miriam to generate greater profits and increase her standard of living. Miriam hopes that in the future she will be able to start up another boutique. 

Miriam is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Miriam who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Byambajav

texts.en: Byambajav is 39 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Bulgan province, Mongolia. Her elder child is a medical college student, while her younger child is a school student. She started her garment retail business in 1997. She is well known for her fashion taste. Now that winter is approaching, she needs warmer clothes to sell. She is a sharp and hard-working woman who says, "Now that my daughter is in college, I have to do everything I can in order to support her." She is requesting 2,500,000 MNT to buy more clothes at wholesale prices.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Batsaikhan

texts.en: Mr. Batsaikhan, 36, is a taxi driver. He lives with his two children and wife in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. He has been running his business for seven years and already has many regular customers. His current ger is quite bad and uncomfortable, and very small for his entire family. Therefore, he decided to build his own house. It is 70% completed. But suddenly he incurred some unplanned expenses for building materials. Therefore he is taking a loan to purchase the necessary building materials to finish his house before this winter.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael is 40 years old and lives in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has seven children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past twenty years, Rachael has been working hard to manage her store, which sells mattresses and bedding. 

To help expand her business, Rachael has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more mattresses for resale, and will help Rachael to generate greater profits and improve the quality of life for her family. Rachael hopes that in the future she will be able to continue growing her business. 

Rachael is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rachael who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more mattresses for resale

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 32-year-old married man and father of two children. He owns a pickle factory since 20 years ago. Ahmad is well known in the region because of his good quality of products he makes. He is a man with a good reputation. Ahmad is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, in order to buy necessary pickles barrels that are needed to preserve more quantities to increase income. 
Ahmad is a hard working man he works his best to provide his family with the best living and education ever. Most of Ahmad's customers are retail food shops. Ahmad works on producing new kinds of pickles from time to time such as eggplants,almonds and many other vegetables.
Ahmad hopes to expand his business more and more in the future.

loans.use: To buy necessary pickles barrels

loans.name: Suleiman

texts.en:
Suleiman is a married man with three children, two of whom are enrolled in school while one is too young for school. His wife is a businesswoman who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. He lives in a rental house with neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food for his family and house rent.

Suleiman has operated a food stall for the past three years; his potential clients are the people who come to the market. He faces a major challenge in the perishability of his products, since he sells fresh products. He aspires to become a vegetable products supplier.

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings, he wants to purchase more stocks of vegetables like potatoes, cabbages and others for his food stall. He decided to join Yehu Microfinance to get financial aid to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of vegetables like potatoes, cabbages and others for his food stall.

loans.name: Tsedevsuren

texts.en:
Tsedevsuren is 28 years old and lives with his wife and son in a ger (a Mongolian nomadic tent) in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His wife helps with his business and his son goes to kindergarden.

He started his cellphone sales and repair business in 2006 by renting a counter in a market. He is well known for his excellent service and quality of his work. He is a hardworking and diligent man who says, "Now that cellphones are getting advanced, my equipment is unable to operate. Therefore, I need new equipment and some raw materials."

He is requesting 2,500,000 to purchase new equipment.

loans.use: to purchase new equipment

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 32 years old and lives in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past ten years, Samuel has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells food and home supplies to local customers. 

To help expand his business, Samuel has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sugar, salt and cooking oil for resale, and will help Samuel to generate greater profits and improve his family's welfare. Samuel hopes that in the future he will be able to continue growing his business. 

Samuel is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Samuel who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro loans.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, salt and cooking oil for resale

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is 29 years old and is a married woman. She has four children, two of whom are in school. She has had a business of selling breads in Kator, South Sudan for five years.

Flora requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase breads. She will use her extra income to build a house in future.

loans.use: to purchase breads for sale

loans.name: Sharshenbu's Group

texts.en:
Sharshenbu is the leader of this group. She is 60 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband, she has raised a son and a daughter. The daughter is employed and the son studies at school.

Ten years ago, with an initial investment of 5,000 soms, the family bought two farm animals for breeding. Reselling the livestock after fattening, Sharshenbu earns about 5,000 soms per month. With money from the loan, she wants to increase the number of livestock.

In the near future, with the profits gained from reselling animals, she plans to purchase household appliances to improve the family’s living conditions. 

======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 26 years old and a married woman. She has three children and one is in school. She has had a business selling breads in Kator, South Sudan for four years.

Esther requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase breads. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay for her child to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase breads for sale

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en: Dolgorsuren is 55 years old and lives with her husband and two kids in Govisumber province, Mongolia. Her husband helps with her business, her elder son lives independently and the younger one is a college student. Dolgorsuren operates a meat trading business. She started her meat trading business in 2000. Now that winter is approaching, she needs to fill her stock and sell it when it becomes more expensive. She has a supply worth MNT 4,000,000 now. Based on this year's demand, her current supply is not sufficient to run the business for the coming year. She is requesting 1,000,000 MNT to buy more meat.

loans.use: To buy more meat

loans.name: Damétote

texts.fr:
Damétote est un homme âgé de 32 ans. Il est marié å une  revendeuse. Il a 01 enfant âgé de 03ans.
Damétote travaille comme revendeur de chemises et chaussures depuis 2007. Il vend de façon ambulante à ses clients.
Damétote a requis son quatrième  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des chaussures. Il veut agrandir l’activité en la diversifiant. 
Il dit qu’avec les profits, Il prévoit assurer la stabilité financière de la famille.
texts.en:
Damétote is a 32-year-old man.  He is married to a retail merchant and has a three-year-old child.

Damétote has been working as an itinerant retail salesman of shirts and shoes since 2007.

Damétote requested his fourth WAGES credit loan to buy shoes. He would like to expand his business activity by diversifying his product offerings.

He stated that the profits should provide financial stability for his family.

loans.use: Buy shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a chair for her hair salon

loans.name: Sinoeun

texts.en:
Sinoeun is 38 years old with 4 children. She is a local buyer of mango fruits which she sells at the market. She is also a farmer. She has been in her business for 8 years. 

This is her second loan with VisionFund. She requested a loan to buy mango fruits for resale and to buy fertilizers for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to increase her mango stock and increase her crop yields to earn more income to buy some necessary household stuff, to have some savings for her family, and also to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy mango fruits for resale and fertilizers for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more routers.

loans.name: Saffa

texts.en:
This is 25-year-old Saffa. He is married and has three children, aged 6, 4 and 3 years. He has three additional dependents who live with him because they are his relatives.  

In 2008, Saffa established his clothing, shoes and belt business. He began his business because he dropped out of school and needed some form of employment to get income to support his family. Working seven days a week and nine hours a day, he earns about 1,800,000 Sierra Leone leones (Le) every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Saffa now requires a new loan in order to buy more women's jeans and men's jeans. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, Saffa plans to give his children a better education and to travel to Dubai. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy men's and women's jeans for his business.

loans.name: Mekhrab

texts.en:
Mekhrab is a farmer from the village of Paris, East Georgia. He is 56 years old, married, and lives with his wife, Dilara, and his 25 year-old son. Mekhrab’s son works as singer in a local restaurant. He is a musician. 

Mekhrab and Dilara are leading the agricultural business of the family. They own 1.3 hectares of land, where potato, maize and pumpkins are grown. Mekhrab sells his products in Tbilisi (capital city of the country). Total average monthly income of the family is 900 Laris (approximately 540 USD). 

Mekhrab requested credit to purchase seeds for potatoes. He will purchase quality seeds and sow them in the plot. During the winter, Mekhrab and Dilara will work hard in order to get a quality harvest. They hope that the weather conditions will be favorable as well, and will sell harvested products for a good price. The family will use the received income for improving family living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase seeds of potatoes

loans.name: Yon

texts.en:
Yon is 44 years old with five children. She runs a grocery shop in her front yard. She sells bananas, eggs, detergent, cakes, etc., and she is also a farmer. Her husband is a fisherman. She has been running her grocery shop for 18 years. 

This is her second loan with VisionFund. She requested a loan to buy grocery stocks for her shop and to buy fertilizers for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to increase her grocery stocks and increase her crop yields, to have some savings for her business and family, and also to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy grocery stocks.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lillian lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with three children, all of whom go to school. She takes care of one additional family member who is an orphan. She sells fruits, vegetables and sweet bananas on a wholesale basis at the market. She has been in business for the last four years. She works six days a week.

She has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more boxes of fruits, vegetables and bunches of sweet bananas. Her goal and aspirations are to start going to villages for fruits like oranges, pineapples, mangoes and sweet bananas, and also to educate her children to the university level. Her major business challenges are seasonality and the increasing prices of foodstuffs in Uganda. 

She lives in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent and food.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of fruits like oranges, mangoes, pineapples and bunches of sweet bananas.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
This is 45-year-old Nancy.  She is married and has three children, aged 23, 18 and 14. In 1998, Nancy established her cosmetics, suitcase, Coleman and DVD laptop business. She began her business because wanted to enhance her independence and be able to provide a livelihood for her family. Working six days a week and nine hours a day, she earns about 1,200,000 Sierra Leone leones (Le) every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. Nancy requires a loan in order to buy more cosmetics, suitcases and DVD laptops for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 400,000. In the future, Nancy plans to build a house and educate her children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics, suitcases and DVDs.

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en: Narantuya is disabled, 45 years old and lives with her husband and two kids in Ger, Mongolian nomadic tent in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia.  Her husband does delivery in the market with his cart, her older son lives independently and younger one studies at school.  She started her business by selling ice-cream in 1999 and since then, she has expanded her business to services like paid phone, prepaid phone card retail and selling underwear. Now that winter is approaching, she is planning on selling warm clothes.  She is a strong and hardworking woman who says "I am disabled, however I never stepped back. I always search for a business opportunity." She is requesting 500,000 MNT to buy winter clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy winter clothes for sale

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza is a 44-year-old married woman, a mother of four children whom she's responsible for.  Aziza is a hard working woman with a good reputation. 
Her previous Kiva loan helped a lot in improving her income and in providing her family a good and healthy living.  She works from her house, and hopes to increase her stock of clothing with autumn/winter collections for sale.  

Aziza assures that her previous loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua helped a lot in improving her social and financial situations and hopes that this one will improve it even more.

loans.use: To expand her store by purchasing new merchandise for the autumn/winter season

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy chairs and tents to rent for special occasions.

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en: Oeun is 54 years old with 7 children. She is a farmer and she also catches fish for additional income. She has been a farmer for 29 years. This is her second loan with VisionFund. She requested a loan to buy fertilizer for her farmland and to plant rice paddy on it. With this loan, she hopes to increase her crop yields to earn more income for family expenses and some savings and also to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to plant rice paddy on her farmland and buy fertilizer.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El comité se ha formado gracias a la iniciativa de una de las miembros que era ex integrante de otro grupo. Ella contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para conformar el grupo en la zona. El comité se denomina “La Esperanza”. Están en el Tercer Ciclo y está constituido por 16 integrantes; es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unido y responsable. Las integrantes poseen un gran espíritu emprendedor, ya que están al día con las cuotas, trabajan en conjunto en  la realización de actividades para recaudar fondos que puedan salvaguardar al comité en caso de necesidad.
Una de ellas es la señora Rosalina, ella tiene una herrería bien equipada, comenta que le va muy bien en el negocio, justamente por tener buena clientela que acude a ella por el buen servicio que presta y también por el buen trabajo. Quiere seguir abasteciendo su negocio, por lo que solicita el crédito, para la compra de indumentarias y utensilios necesarios para la herrería, como ser hierros, chapas, pinturas y demás. Está agradecida a la fundación y kiva por la oportunidad que le dan.
texts.en:
This committee was formed thanks to the initiative of one of its members who used to belong to another group.  She contacted her friends and neighbors to form this group in her area.  The committee is called 'La Esperanza' (Hope) and its sixteen members are in their third loan cycle.  This is a group which stands out in the neighborhood for its unity and responsibility.  The members of the group have a great entrepreneurial spirit.  They are up to date with their repayments and they work together on different activities to collect funds which can save the committee should the need arise.

One of the members of the committee is Rosalina, who has a well-stocked blacksmith's.  She tells us that her business is going very well because she has good customers who come to her for the good service that she provides and for her good work.  She would like to continue stocking her business and so is requesting a loan to buy clothing and tools which she needs for her blacksmith's such as iron, sheets of metal, paints, etc.  She is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva for the opportunity that they are giving her.

loans.use: to buy iron, sheets of metal, paint and other products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Gnor

texts.en: Gnor is 39 years old with 4 children. She is a farmer and she also grows vegetable for her additional income. She has been a farmer for 20 years. This is her second loan with VisionFund. She requested a loan to buy fertilizers for her farmland and seeds for vegetable planting. With this loan, she hopes to increase her crop yields from her rice and vegetable plantings and have more income for savings and a better house.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland and seeds for vegetable planting

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Jitta

texts.en:
This is 38 year-old Jitta.  She is married, and has 4 children aged 20,14, 8 and 5.  She also has 4 additional dependents, who live with her.  

In 1996, Jitta established her Cosmetic and drinks business.  Working 7 days a week and 9 hours a day, she earns about Le 1,300, 000 every month.

She would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000 to buy soft drinks and cosmetics for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. 

In the future, Jitta plans to build a house, open a bigger shop and educate her children to the university level.   She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy cosmetic and drinks for her business.

loans.name: Muath

texts.en:
Muath is a 24 years old, single man, from Tulkarem.  He sells cleaning equipment. 

With this loan, he will buy a machine to help disburse cleaning products.  

He believes that this will help him have a more successful business, and help him financially.

loans.use: to buy a machine to help disburse cleaning products.

loans.name: Mujeres Bonitas Group

texts.es:
El comité se ha formado gracias al apoyo de la señora Mariana. Ella contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para conformar el grupo en la zona. El comité se denomina “Mujeres Bonitas”. Están en el Primer Ciclo y está constituido por 15  integrantes. Tienen un gran espíritu emprendedor, trabajan en conjunto para realizar actividades para recaudar fondos que puedan salvaguardar al comité en caso de necesidad.
La señora Mariana se dedica a la venta de plantas ornamentales, comenta que tiene buenas ventas, ya que tiene muchas clientas que gustan de las plantas que vende. Gracias a este trabajo ella logra aportar para los gastos diarios de la casa.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de plantas, con lo cual podrá tener más variedad para mostrar a sus clientes y de paso atraer a más.
texts.en:
This committee was formed thanks to the support of Mariana who contacted her friends and neighbors to form the group in her area.  The committee is called 'Mujeres Bonitas' (Beautiful Women) and its fifteen members are in their first loan cycle.  They have a great entrepreneurial spirit and work together to carry out activities to collect funds which can save the committee should the need arise.

Mariana's business is selling ornamental plants.  She tells us that she has good sales as she has a lot of customers who like the plants that she sells.  Thanks to this work she manages to contribute towards covering her household's daily expenses.  Mariana is requesting this loan to buy plants which will give her a greater variety to show her customers and, at the same time, attract new customers.

loans.use: to buy ornamental plants for resale

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine lives in Kampala, Uganda.  She is married with 6 school age children. 

Christine runs a food stall, selling fruits, vegetables and dry fish on a retail basis at the market. She has been in business for the last year.  Christine works six days a week .

She has requested a loan of 2000000 from MCDT SACCO to buy more vegetables like cabbages, tomatoes, fish, and ground nuts.  Her major business challenges are seasonality and transportation. 

Christine gets additional income through rental rooms and a small retail shop.  Her goals and aspirations are to build more rental houses and to own a fully stocked food stall.  She lives in her own house and her family has access to electricity but not to piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees, medication and food.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables like cabbages, tomatoes, dried fish  and  ground nuts.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Phalla is 50 years old and married with 4 children. She is a vegetable farmer who has worker in the field for 22 years. 

This is her second loan with VisionFund.  Phalla requested a loan to buy fertilizers for her farmland and seeds to grow vegetables. 

With this loan, she hopes to increase her crop yields from rice and vegetables, earn more income, savings and live in a better house.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland and seeds for vegetables plantation

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en:
This is 43 year-old Abdul.  He is married, and has 4 children aged 19, 16, 13 and 10 years.  He has 2 additional dependents, who live with him.  

In 2001, Abdul established his drinks business to generate funds to support his children's education.  Working 7 days a week and 14 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,000,000 every month.  

He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 to buy soft drinks, beer, stout Carlsberg and Heineken.  He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. 

In the future, Abdul plans to establish a more decent bar with modern facilities and to become a distributor for a brewery.  He thank you for your support.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, beer.

loans.name: Dieu Sauveur Group

texts.fr:
Mme K.Dibaramin est la représentante du groupe DIEU SAUVEUR .Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 05ans et le moins âgé a 01an. Un va à l’école. Elle a 04 personnes en charge.

Elle vend des objets  plastiques (plats, gobelets, sceaux, caraffes, etc.) et des condiments depuis 10ans. Elle s’approvisionne au marché du secteur 10. Ses clients sont les femmes et  quelques hommes.

Elle veut  acheter par douzaine quelques objets plastiques et un peu de condiments.

Mme  économise pour agrandir son hangar. Elle ambitionne s’acheter une moto afin de pouvoir se promener dans les petits marchés  pour vendre ses marchandises .
texts.en:
Mrs. K. Dibaramin is the representative of the  “Dieu Sauveur”  [God the Saviour] group. She is married and the mother of two children.  The older is five years old, and the  younger is one year old. One child is in school. She has four dependents.

She sells plastic items (dishes, cups, pails, pitchers etc) and condiments for 10 years. She stocks up at the Sector 10 market. Her clients are [mostly] women and sometimes men. She would like to buy plastic items by the dozen and some condiments.

She is saving up to expand her storage shed. Her goal is to buy a motorbike in order to be able to go to small markets in order to sell her merchandise.

loans.use: to buy plastic items by the dozen and some condiments

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith lives in Kampala, Uganda.  She is married with 2 school aged children. She also has one additional family member. 

She sells bananas on a wholesale basis at the market.  Edith has been in business for over ten years.  She works seven days a week.  Her major business challenges are seasonality and transportation.

Edith has requested a loan of 2000000 from MCDT SACCO to buy more bananas.  

Her goals and aspirations are to go to farmers for bananas, buy a motor van to ease transportation and to build rental houses. 

She lives in a rented house and her family has access to electricity but not to piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent and food.

loans.use: to buy more bananas.

loans.name: San Miguel Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre San Miguel, se conformó en septiembre del año 2007.  Formaron un grupo de 17 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto ya en el decimo ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa. Ellas manifiestan que les gustaría seguir con la fundación, ya que les ha sido de mucha ayuda.
Natalia, una de las miembros, se dedica a la venta de lencería, tanto para hombres como para mujeres, negocio al que se dedica hace un tiempo, gracias al cual obtiene los ingresos necesarios para ayudar con los gastos de la casa. Comenta que la fundación la ha ayudado mucho en su negocio, por lo que solicita nuevamente su ayuda por medio del crédito para la compra de lencerías masculinas y femeninas, para poder seguir con sus ventas. Agradece por esta oportunidad que se le da.
texts.en:
The San Miguel Women's Committee was formed in September 2007 by a group of 17 women.  They are currently working very happily on their tenth loan cycle in a joint and supportive manner within the program.  They say that they would like to continue working with the foundation as it has been very helpful to them.

One of the group's members, Natalia, sells underwear for both men and women.  She has been in this business for some time and it makes her the income she needs to help with her household expenses.  She says that the foundation have helped her a lot in her business and so she is requesting their help again through this loan which she will use to buy men's and women's underwear.  This will enable her to continue with her sales.  She is grateful for this opportunity that she is being given.

loans.use: to buy men's and women's underwear for resale

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Hun is 46 years old and married with 3 children. She is a cucumber farmer and has been in business for 10 years. 

This is her first loan with VisionFund.  Hun requests a loan to buy fertilizers for her farmland and to buy seeds to grow vegetables. 

With this loan, Hun hopes to increase her crop yield, earn more income and saving money to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland and seeds for vegetables planting.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Rabiaa

texts.en:
Rabiaa is a 32-year-old married woman and mother of three children.  

She sells women clothes, is hard working and has been in business for three years.  Rabiaa is a talented business woman who has a very good reputation.

She requests a loan from Kiva partner A. Mjamoua so she can start selling women lingerie.  Rabiaa works hard to introduce her customers to this new section of her shop and plans to develop it and increase sales more and more in the future.

Rabiaa wishes to open a shop that sells family clothes and shoes.

loans.use: to increase her business products by selling lingerie.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 26 years old. She is married and has two children who are enrolled in school. 

Alice and her husband sell foodstuffs and have spent five years in this business.  

She requests a loan to increase her store inventory, by buying beans, bananas and maize.  

Alice is likely to use the profits to renovate her house and to provide food for her family.  She dreams to have her own car to help with the business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more foodstuffs for resell.

loans.name: Felix

texts.en:
Felix, 39, is married with 3 school aged children who range between 5 and 11 years old. 

He requests a loan to buy construction supplies to increase his store's inventory.  He has been in business for seven years.

Felix expects to use the profits from his business to star another business.

loans.use: to buy more construction supplies.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary  lives in Kampala, Uganda.  She is married with three children and they all go to school. She takes care of one additional family member (a brother). 

She is a market vendor at Kalerwe market. She sells matooke, vegetables and fruits at the market on a retail basis. She has been in business for the last six years. She works seven days a week.

She has requested a loan of 400,000 from Kiva partner MCDT SACCO to buy more bunches of green bananas, fresh beans, and vegetables. Her goals and aspirations are to own another stall in the same market and also to buy a plot of land. Her major business challenges are thieves and seasonality. 

She lives in a  rented house and the family has access to electricity but no access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent  and food.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 25 years-old. She is married with two children, between one and six years old. All her children go to school. Elizabeth sells used shoes, and she has been in this business for more than one year. She has asked for this loan to buy more shoes to resell. Elizabeth needs to use the profits from her business to renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy more shoes to sell.

loans.name: Unisa

texts.en:
This is 36 year-old Unisa.  He is married, and has two children aged 11 and two years. He has two additional dependents, who live with him. 

In 1997, Unisa established his provisions shop.  It sells items such as mayonnaise, sardines, milk powder, butter, milk, choco show, soap and cigarettes. He began his business because he wanted help to abandon his shepherd job as he was a cattle raiser in the bush. Working seven days a week and 16 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,000,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000. 

Unisa requires a new loan in order to buy items to sell.  He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, Unisa plans to establish a larger business, to travel to the holy land and to give his children a quality education.   He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy mayonnaise, sardines, milk powder, butter, milk, choco show, soap and cigarettes.

loans.name: Tembiapo Pora Group

texts.es:
Tembiapo pora se denomina el excelente grupo de mujeres conformado en la ciudad de Ita, gracias a que la Sra. Luz contactó con la asesora en una de las  reuniones que esta tenía en la zona para informarse de la forma de trabajo que tiene el Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, y una vez asesorada juntó a 16 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando ya en el noveno ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
La señora Luz se dedica a la venta de ao po’i (ropas típicas paraguayas, bordadas), nos comenta que tiene muy buena venta, ya que es muy solicitada la ropa de ao po’i. Muchas personas, en especial turistas lo admiran mucho. Ella sueña con poder expandirse y que sus prendas vayan al exterior.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de hilos y bastidores, los cuales son esenciales para la elaboración de las prendas que vende. Agradece por la oportunidad que se le da a ella y también a su comité.
texts.en:
These excellent women are members of the Tembiapo Pora group in the city of Ita, thanks to Sra. Luz, who got in touch with an advisor to the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras at one of the meetings she had in the area in order to become better informed about the work the Comité was doing. Once informed, Sra. Luz brought 16 women together, who are now working supportively, in their ninth loan cycle within the program.

Sra. Luz sells ao po’i (typical embroidered Paraguayan clothes) and tells us that she has very good sales since ao po’i  clothing is in high demand. Many people, particularly tourists, admire it greatly. She dreams of being able to expand so that her clothing items are sold abroad.

She is requesting this loan in order to buy thread and embroidery frames, which are essential in making the items she sells. She is grateful for the opportunity given to her and also to the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, a program of Fundación Paraguaya.

loans.use: to buy thread and embroidery frames to make ao po’i  (traditional Paraguayan clothing).

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.en: Alphonsine, sells clothes. She is married to a businessman. They have four children aged between three and 14. They all go to school. She requested the loan to increase her business of clothes. She expects to use the profits from this business to build her house. She expects to have a large merchandise in the future.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Thavy

texts.en: Thavy is married with six children. She is a 45 year-old farmer. Her children are still in school. She has been a farmer for 25 years. This is her third loan with Kiva partner VisionFund. She requested a loan to buy fertilizers for her farmland and to plant rice paddy. With this loan, she hopes to increase her crop yields to a good quality in order to sell at a better price, to have some savings and also to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Julian Ricardo

texts.es:
El señor  Julian está casado, tiene 3 hijos en edad escolar. El se dedica a la fabricación y reparación de calzados, tiene su negocio en su domicilio,  en la ciudad de San Lorenzo, se inicio en este rubro con sus padres ya que se dedicaba a lo mismo, y con un poco de capital logro montar su propio negocio. 
Comenta que tiene buena clientela debido a su buena atención y al buen trabajo que realiza. Dice que desea ampliar su negocio y dar fuente de trabajo a las personas de su ciudad. Es por ello que se esfuerza cada día más y más.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de cueros, lo cuales le servirán para la elaboración de  los calzados que vende.
texts.en:
Julián is married and has three, school age children.  He manufactures and repairs shoes.  His business is home-based in the city of San Lorenzo.  He started this line of work with his parents since they were in the same business and with a little bit of capital he was able to start his own business.

He comments that he has a good clientele because of the good work he does and the good customer care.  He says that he’d like to expand the business and provide employment for people from his city. Because of this he puts more effort into it every day.

He is asking for the loan to buy leather to make the shoes he sells.

loans.use: to buy shoe leather.

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Nuru  lives in  Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.  Nuru has a business of selling bananas.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week.  Nuru sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale/retail.

Nuru has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas.The main business challenge(s) for Nuru include defaulters and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become a wholesaler and also to start going to villages for bananas. Nuru lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, market dues and paying for electricity bills.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas.

loans.name: Avance Group

texts.fr: AVANCE est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier au Bénin. La représentante du groupe, Bérénice Innocentia (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 32 ans et est mariée à un couturier du nom de Morel. Le couple a un enfant qui est scolarisé et à leur charge. Bérénice Innocentia vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant. Le couple se partage les diverses charges familiales. Bérénice Innocentia a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Il y a près de quatre ans que Bérénice Innocentia vend des chaussures, sacs et tissus par le système de distribution.Bérénice Innocentia  exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins. Bérénice Innocentia  s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin et à Lomè. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et en vue d’augmenter son fonds de roulement, Bérénice Innocentia  sollicite un troisième crédit avec les autres membres du groupe AVANCE. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en: Avance is a group of three people whose members live in the same neighbourhood in Benin. The leader of the group, Berenice Innocentia (who has her hand raised on the photo) is 32 years old and married to a tailor called Morel. The coupled has one child whose school fees are paid by his parents. Berenice Innocentia lives with her child and her husband. The couple shares the different family expenses. Berenice Innocentia stopped going to school during secondary classes. Berenice Innocentia has been selling shoes, bags, and fabrics by the distribution system for nearly four years. Berenice Innocentia loves her work which enables her to provide for herself. Berenice Innocentia buys her stock in a market in Benin and at Lomé. In the hope of satisfying her customers and to increase her working capital, Berenice Innocentia requests a third loan with the other members of the group Avance.This loan will enable them to improve their supply to the demands of their customers and to make more profits.

loans.use: to purchase shoes,bags and fabrics.
